title: Mont-de-Marsan
text:
Mont-de-Marsan (; <a href="Gascon%20language">Gascon</a>: "Lo Mont de Marçan") is a <a href="communes%20of%20France">commune</a> and capital of the <a href="Landes%20%28department%29">Landes</a> <a href="Departments%20of%20France">department</a>, <a href="New%20Aquitaine">New Aquitaine</a>, southwestern France.
Military installations.
The <a href="French%20Air%20and%20Space%20Force">French Air and Space Force</a> operates the "<a href="Constantin%20Rozanoff">Constantin Rozanoff</a>" <a href="Mont-de-Marsan%20Air%20Base">Mont-de-Marsan Air Base</a> about 2 kilometres north of the town. The base includes <a href="CEAM">CEAM</a> (the French air force military experimentation and trials organisation), an air defense radar command reporting centre and an air defence control training site. Mont-de-Marsan Air Base was formerly home to France's first operational squadron of nuclear bombers, the <a href="Dassault%20Mirage%20IV">Dassault Mirage IV</a>A.
Culture.
Stade Montois Club Omnisports is the city's main sports club, known for its <a href="Rugby%20union">rugby</a> team <a href="Stade%20Montois">Stade Montois</a> and its <a href="association%20football">football</a> team <a href="Stade%20Montois%20%28football%29">Stade Montois (football)</a>. The city has around 9,000 sports licensees, which is nearly 30% of the total population.
Two historic <a href="punk%20rock">punk rock</a> music festivals were held in Mont-de-Marsan's bullring in 1976 and 1977.
Festival Arte Flamenco international festival created in 1989 in Mont-de-Marsan by the council of the Landes department.
International relations.
